item.title: 9 Details We Spotted In Pok√©mon Winds And Waves‚Äô First Trailer
item.content:encoded:
This morning, Game Freak officially announced Pok√©mon Winds and Waves, the games that will kick off the next generation on Switch 2 next year. We saw around three minutes of footage of the game in motion, and though it is brief, there‚Äôs a fair bit to glean from what we saw. Let‚Äôs break down the first trailer.

The opening cinematic pays tribute to 30 years of Pok√©mon

Starting off the trailer is a cinematic showing several illustrations of a Pikachu traveling around the Pok√©mon world. Each drawing shows Pikachu in a different region from the first nine generations, from Kanto in Red and Blue to Paldea in Scarlet and Violet. It‚Äôs a cute way to lead into the next generation and also pay homage to the series‚Äô 30th anniversary. As the trainer flips through their scrapbook, we end on an image of Pikachu looking out a window to a beach, which is revealed to be the space we‚Äôre in now.

Who are these Pikachu?

After strolling through memory lane, the trainer opens their house door and is greeted by two Pikachu that are glammed up and also notably darker than the average mouse, so fans are speculating that they‚Äôre Shiny. Their names are Mr. Windychu and Ms. Wavychu, but we don‚Äôt know much about how they‚Äôre involved in the story just yet. Given their names, they might be exclusive to the different versions similar to the professors in Scarlet and Violet, but that‚Äôs just a theory.

Well, it certainly looks better than Scarlet and Violet

Winds and Waves is the next open-world game in the Pok√©mon series, and for whatever it‚Äôs worth, it does look like a significant graphical improvement over Scarlet and Violet, which was raked through the coals for looking like a GameCube game. The environments have texture and character to them, which is more than you could say for the bland, flat appearance of the Paldea region. Could this finally be the end of the Pok√©mon graphics debates? Arceus, I hope so.

The new region feels like a bit of a throwback

While a lot of recent Pok√©mon games have been defined by city skylines, Winds and Waves seems like it has a much more nature-driven region than the series has routinely sported of late. Yeah, there are some human structures like what appears to be a giant water-based lab, but by and large we don‚Äôt see much of human civilization, and it gives it more of that grounded, earthy feel that is much more akin to previous generations. It makes me wonder if it will have the same gyms and Pok√©mon League structure of previous games, or if we might be spending more time exploring the wild environment instead.

Different outfits for both games

Like Scarlet and Violet, Winds and Waves will change some of the player‚Äôs outfit accents depending on which version they‚Äôre playing. It‚Äôs unclear if this is justified in the story the way it was by having different school uniforms in Scarlet and Violet, but the Winds protagonist sports a white and blue rancher hat, while the Waves hero wears a darker blue cap. Hopefully Winds and Waves doesn‚Äôt pull back on the excellent fashion and customization options from Legends: Z-A and we still get a plethora of looks and outfits to choose from.

The Pok√©dex seems eclectic

We didn‚Äôt see many of the new Pok√©mon that will debut in Winds and Waves, but we did see a lot of the returning ones and it looks like a nice spread from the previous nine generations. So don‚Äôt worry too much about it being another Kanto-filled adventure.

Pikachu didn‚Äôt get a makeover

Early leaks for Winds and Waves included what appeared to be a redesign for Pikachu that would have further slimmed him down from his original round look. However, based on the footage we‚Äôve seen, it looks like Game Freak didn‚Äôt use this updated design, which is fine by me.

The starters are the star of the show

The only new Pok√©mon we saw in this first trailer are the three starters: Browt, Pombon, and Gecqua. The grass-type bird is described as ‚Äúlively, but it can also be a bit clumsy‚Äù and we know it photosynthesizes the leaves on its brow. Pombon is a Pomeranian fire dog that has a ‚Äúheat-generating organ within its lungs‚Äù and is ‚Äúguileless and friendly.‚Äù Lastly, Gecqua rounds out the trio with its water attacks that it springs from its tail, and is ‚Äúintelligent and maneuvers shrewdly while putting on airs‚Äã.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a focus on underwater exploration

Game Freak made a point to focus on underwater exploration, which is one of the new ways you‚Äôll be able to move through the environment in Winds and Waves‚Äô open world. It‚Äôs unclear how we‚Äôll do that, whether it‚Äôs through some kind of vehicle or if Dive is returning from the previous games, but it looks like you‚Äôll be able to encounter wild water Pok√©mon under the sea, rather than just having to fish for them or see them swimming at the surface.

Ugh, they‚Äôre gonna make me wait for it

I guess now that Scarlet and Violet was a huge technical disaster, Game Freak is trying to put more space between each of its games. Winds and Waves are coming to Switch 2 in 2027, which means we‚Äôll probably have about a two-year gap between it and Legends: Z-A, which came out in October of last year. The company didn‚Äôt get any more specific than the year, though, so the games could conceivably launch in the first half of 2027. I‚Äôll just have to sustain myself on Pokopia for a while.

item.title: Pok√©mon Winds And Waves Starters Revealed, And They‚Äôre Cuties
item.content:encoded:
As is by now traditional, the initial announcement of the existence of Pok√©mon Winds And Waves was accompanied by the reveal of the three new starter Pok√©mon that trainers will be able to choose from at the beginning of the game, and by extension the first three Pok√©mon revealed as part of Gen X. They are Browt, Pombon and Gecqua. Let‚Äôs meet ‚Äôem.

Browt

First up is Browt, an owl-ish baby bird with big eyebrows. Just imagine the long nights spent trying to figure out that name. It‚Äôs the Grass-type starter, described as a Bean Chick Pok√©mon, and we already have its vital stats:

Height: 1‚Ä≤ (0.3m)
Weight: 7.7lb (3.5KG)
Ability: Overgrow

It does seem a bit odd that the game‚Äôs gone back to owls as a starter inspiration, given Rowlet was only three generations ago. Although this might be more bizarre design choice than actual species, given it‚Äôs described as a ‚Äúchick.‚Äù Given the leaf-like brows on the beast, we can assume it‚Äôll lean into those Bulbasaur-like planty attacks.

Pombon

This fluffy pup is yet another dog-like pocket monster, although the first time one‚Äôs been a starter. It‚Äôs the Fire-type for the set, and classified as a Puppy Pok√©mon. Its stats are:

Height: 1‚Äô4 (0.4m)
Weight: 14.8lb (4.3KG)

There‚Äôs not a lot more to discern about this little doggo, other than its obvious inspiration by a Pomeranian. It‚Äôll be interesting to see if it stays cute as it grows, or if things head in a more wolf-like direction.

Gecqua

Hardest to spell is Gecqua, who we can infer from the name alone is an aquatic gecko. Water-type, of course, and with its huge eyes my immediate favorite of the three, with the unimaginative category of Water Gecko Pok√©mon. Stats are:

Height: 1‚Ä≤ (0.3m)
Weight: 9.5lb (4.3KG)

It was only Gen VIII that we last saw a reptilian starter, and a Water-type to boot, with Sobble. And given the visual similarity between the two, especially when you think about Sobble‚Äôs final form, Inteleon, it‚Äôs another oddly overlapping design. Still though, Gecqua is completely adorable and is already my pick.

So, who stands out to you? Have you already fallen in love? Or are you just bemused that Game Freak couldn‚Äôt think of any other species to be inspired by for the new starters?
